awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Coding the Affective Domain and Visuospatial Ability
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project supports the development of a visuospatial educational assessment tool.  Visuospatial aptitude is a facet of intelligence that underlies innovative thinking, i.e., how do new ideas emerge? and What are the physiological processes involved? Today, there is an overwhelming exposure within society to digital visual stimuli and national assessment authorities acknowledge visuospatial abstract reasoning as an accepted and sought after cognitive ability. Future curriculum designs must develop along with how people are changing and perceiving knowledge. This project seeks to set standards in education on visuospatial ability by introducing a novel assessment. This visuospatial assessment tool will utilize a software platform that allows customers to take the assessment online, and has commercial potential to improve industry, science, and educational programs for the advancement of human communication.

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project investigates the development of an information technology consisting of a visuospatial ability assessment for measuring the biological processes that are required for being creative. Humans are biologically predisposed both to perceive and to reproduce symmetry, mainly in visual form, but also aurally; This proposed visuospatial assessment tool measures some of the biological processes that are required for the perception and reproduction of symmetry. Specifically, this assessment measures a form of sensorimotor perceptual action referred to in this project as ‘affective symmetry gauging’ (ASG). ASG consists of a subject’s innate visual perception/identification of the division in extreme and mean ratio point (DEMR; i.e., the symmetry point) in a given pattern. Because this process measures the extent to which a subject can perceive/identify and reproduce the symmetry point in given patterns, the tool also suggests the degree to which a subject may be inclined to reproduce symmetry, marking this inclination as a natural human expression of creativity aligned to pleasingness.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

NSF SBIR Phase I Project Outcomes Report

 

 

 

The Visuospatial Education Center (VEC EDU) was awarded a National Science Foundation (NSF) Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Merit Award and grant on August 15, 2022. VEC EDU has completed its initial research project that investigated a quantitative mathematical parameter and six qualitative psychophysics measurements to add to an array of assessment tools produced by VEC EDU for a new Creative Test© that visuospatially measures and assesses some of the biological processes that are required for being creative.  The Creative Test© does this by revealing and measuring a person’s affective symmetry gauging (ASG) preference judgement response. The ‘ASG preference’ is a natural visualization ability (gauging for a specifically pleasing point) that has evolved in humans as a result of our three-dimensional physical world. VEC EDU’s Creative Test©/ASG assessment works in the following way: humans are biologically predisposed both to perceive and reproduce symmetry, mainly in visual form, but also aurally. Our visuospatial assessment tool measures some of the biological processes that are required for the perception and reproduction of symmetry. Specifically, our assessment measures the form of sensorimotor perceptual action we refer to as ASG, which consists of a subject’s innate visual perception/identification of the division in extreme and mean ratio point (DEMR; i.e., the symmetry point) in a given pattern. Because this ASG process measures the extent to which a subject can perceive/identify and reproduce the symmetry point in given patterns, our tool also suggests the degree to which a subject may be inclined to reproduce symmetry, marking this inclination as a natural human expression of creativity aligned to pleasingness (i.e., aligned to affect; hence, ‘affective symmetry gauging’). Physiological factors relating to the ASG are thus measurable, and can indicate the likelihood of an individual’s ability to choose to use their natural system of geometric perception to align with their sensory modalities and thereby to develop ideation fluency i.e., their creativity. VEC EDU’s ongoing visualization-assessments research is intellectually meritorious due to its identification of human psychophysics preference judgments that connect to a novel,  77-step mathematical proof consisting of an equiangular spiral motion system geometric construction (the intellectual property (IP) created by Dr. Theresa Ferg and managed at the University of Colorado Tech Transfer Office, reference case number CU1192D).

The VEC EDU Creative Test© can be used for educational purposes in order to identify whether an individual is facilitating their natural visuospatial ability or negating its effects. Being open to creativity while learning allows both student and teacher to explore multiple methods of curricular avenues that address different learning styles for students and teachers.

 

There has not been a new creative assessment since 1972 when the self-reported Torrance Tests of Creative Thinking (TTCT) were first introduced to determine if an individual uses primarily convergent or divergent thought processes. Discovering new ways to assess the creativity and receptivity of both students and teachers toward improving their natural visuospatial ability for social, emotional learning (SEL) increases positive educational outcomes. The Creative Test© is particularly useful insofar as VEC EDU has also developed techniques for shifting a person’s emotional state to a positive direction through leveraging their ASG preference response in communication with others. VEC EDU offers its state-of-the-art academic support and continuing research for a creativity assessment online in a modality that may be particularly useful for educators around the world. Finally, VEC EDU continues to lead in the psychophysics preferential judgment science field with innovations in perceptual knowledge and related instructional tools, such as, an Objective Emotional Approach© for the classroom. Using novel coding methods, VEC EDU is poised to continue its pathbreaking research through conducting far-peripheral visual field tests related to projective geometry in visualization processes. There also is an ongoing community need for VEC EDU to disseminate its research about natural visualization systems and its research about the relationship between human physiology and digital technology. This is important because the more we understand about our natural visualization abilities, the better we can assess the effects on human societies of digital technology innovations.
